page.title: 16THE SCHOOL MEALS SERVICE
page.content: {Subsidised meals}for the public began during the{39/45 war}in{'British {Restaurants'}at one shilling cost. From this developed the{Schools Meals {Service.}New schools built had kitchens. Teachers supervised the meals. This service filled a social need in the lean times following the war. It had been maintained by successive governments. Costs have risen and in the present financial climate cuts have been made and prices increased to reduce the subsidy. In {November '85}the kitchens at{Holy {Cross Juniors,}employed three ladies for a total of 57 hours per week. A pupil paid{66p for a meal.}In one week {675 meals}were{served.}Of these,{131 were{free}because of relative poverty. About{700 children}brought{their own {food}to eat at school.
